description: An overview of the scientific foundations of nutrition. The focus is on the functions, food sources and metabolism of carbohydrate,fat, protein, vitamins and minerals. Effects of deficiency and excess are discussed and dietary recommendations for disease prevention are emphasized. Current issues and controversies are highlighted. Students will analyze their own dietary intakes and develop plans for future actions.
name: NUTRITION: SCIENCE & APPLICATIONS

values.comments:
An overview of the scientific foundations of nutrition.  The focus is on the functions, food sources and metabolism of carbohydrate, fat, protein, vitamins and minerals.  Effects of deficiency and excess are discussed and dietary recommendations for disease prevention are emphasized.  Current issues and controversies are highlighted.  Students will analyze their own dietary intakes and develop plans for future actions.
Students found this class interesting and useful.  The information learned in class was easy to apply to everyday life.  Many students found that they were more conscious of the ways in which different nutrients affect them.  The majority of students were thoroughly please with this class.
Students felt that “class was interesting and tests directly reflective of what was learned, while still requiring a lot of thought.”  This class is intended for non-nursing majors.

An overview of the scientific foundations of nutrition.  The focus is on the functions, food sources and metabolism of carbohydrate, fat, protein, vitamins and minerals.  Effects of deficiency and excess are discussed and dietary recommendations for disease prevention are emphasized.  Current issues and controversies are highlighted.  Students will analyze their own dietary intakes and develop plans for future actions.

	Students were pleased with the introduction to nutrition as a whole. One student found the course very easy overall, while another noted that the difficulty varied immensely by topic. The course does not involve homework or projects, but the exams were said to be on the challenging side.

	Several reviewers commented that Professor De Jonghe was a great instructor, keeping class engaging even when the lecture material seemed boring.

This course is intended for non-nursing majors.
